Finding aid encoded by the Library of Congress Geography & Map Division

did.head: Collection Summary

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English, Vietnamese, and Russian

corpname.part: Geography & Map Division, Library of Congress

did.abstract: The collection consists of 72 maps, and the most unique among them is an annotated map of the Battle of Tan Canh that occurred during the U.S. drawdown from the war in 1972. The other items include a disbound atlas of South Vietnam; various maps of North and South Vietnam; and U.S. military maps of South Vietnam and Cambodia. The materials appear to have been used by Sheehan in preparation of his 1988 book, A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

title.part: Former title of the collection: Neil Sheehan papers
Former title of the collection: Vann-Sheehan Vietnam War collection

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: This material with accession number 20,919 was transferred to the Geography and Map Division from the Manuscript Division in 1994.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was arranged and described by Ryan Moore in 2016.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright of Neil Sheehan map collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Neil Sheehan map collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Geography & Map Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Neil Sheehan map collection, Geography & Map Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Cornelius Mahoney “Neil” Sheehan (1936- ) is a journalist best known for his reporting on the Pentagon Papers, a secret Department of Defense study of the U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Sheehan, when working as a reporter for The New York Times in 1971, obtained the classified documents from Daniel Ellsberg, a military analyst employed by the RAND Corporation. The papers revealed that the U.S. had secretly enlarged the scale of the Vietnam War with the bombings of nearby Cambodia and Laos, and coastal raids on North Vietnam, none of which were reported in the mainstream media. The government attempted to prosecute Ellsberg but the charges were later dropped. In 2011, the Pentagon Papers were declassified and publicly released.

Sheehan published other articles and books on the Vietnam War, including the 1988 book, A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam. It won the Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction and the National Book Award for Nonfiction.

chronitem.event: Night editor, Asian bureau, United Press International, Tokyo, Japan.
Saigon bureau chief, United Press International, Saigon, South Vietnam.
Metropolitan desk and general assignment reporter, New York Times.
Indonesia correspondent, New York Times, Djakarta, Indonesia.
Vietnam correspondent, New York Times , Saigon, South Vietnam.
Defense Department correspondent, New York Times , Washington, D.C., bureau.
White House correspondent, New York Times , Washington, D.C., bureau.
National security affairs correspondent, New York Times , Washington, D.C., bureau.
Published The Arnheiter Affair (New York: Random House). Began leave of absence from the New York Times to write a biography of John Paul Vann.
Resigned from the New York Times.
Published A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam (New York: Random House) Received National Book Award.
Published After the War Was Over: Hanoi and Saigon (New York: Random House).

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in five series

list.item: Series II Annotated map of Pleiku, South Vietnam
Series III Sheets from Atlas of Southeast Asia
Series IV Maps of North and South Vietnam
Series V U.S. military maps of South Vietnam and Cambodia

scopecontent.p: Two battle maps annotated in grease pencil.

odd.p: The map was prepared for Neil Sheehan at the 23rd Division near Pleiku in 1972.
Drawn by Col. R.M. Rhotenberry, a senior advisor to ARVN 23rd Division. Red lines represent North Vietnamese Army and black lines ARVN.
Portion of text that accompanies map: "Sketch shows how close NVA attacking from above and below the town came to linking up and then being to wheel and overrun Division C.P."

Portion of text that accompanies map: "Tan Canh, Battle of 1972. U.S. Army map give to me by Col. Phillip Kaplan, senior advisor to ARVN 22nd, showing ARVN and NVA dispositions and other events during the final phase of battle. Drawn while I interviewed him in Binh Dinh Province, where reorganized 22nd then stationed later in 1972. Interview was at Firebase Crystal."

did.unittitle: Annotated map of Pleiku, South Vietnam
Sheets from Atlas of Southeast Asia

scopecontent.p: Consists of 24 maps and administrative atlas of South Vietnam from 1972 to 1987.

did.unittitle: Indochina Industry, Mining, and Electric Power
South Vietnam Communist Administrative Divisions and Military Regions April 1973

odd.p: Economic, Vegetation, Ethnic Groups, Administrative and Population

Azimuthal Equidistant Projection Centered on Saigon

did.didnote: Airline Map that includes maps of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City

South Vietnam South Sheet Major Road Network 1973
Maps of North and South Vietnam

scopecontent.p: Includes 14 maps of North and South Vietnam, including maps of Hanoi and Saigon published between 1964 and 1971.

did.unittitle: South Vietnam Provincial Administrative Maps October 1969 1969
Vietnam Demarcation Line and Demiliterized Zone
Indochina with Universal Transverse Mercator Grid 1972
Indochina Bathymetry and Areas Subject to Flooding 1970
U.S. military maps of South Vietnam and Cambodia

scopecontent.p: Consists of 33 maps of Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, South Vietnam, and Indochina as a whole from 1965 to 1972 published by U.S. Army Map service, U.S. Army, 29th Engineer Battalion, Central Intelligence Agency, and Defense Mapping Agency.
